snippet: Ashraf Pahlavi, twin sister of the shah of Iran and a crusading women’s rights advocate, found refuge in No. 29, while Paul Rudolph, the cerebral modernist and dean of the Yale School of Architecture, turned No. 23 into his personal laboratory.
abstract: The Appraisal column on secluded Beekman Place, which overlooks the East River in Manhattan; notes that remoteness of the street, one of the shortest on the island, brought two iconoclasts to the same block in the 1970s; Ashraf Pahlavi, twin sister of the shah of Iran, found refuge in 29 Beekman Place, and Paul Rudolph, dean of the Yale School of Architecture, turned 23 Beekman into a personal laboratory.
lead_paragraph: Ashraf Pahlavi, twin sister of the shah of Iran and a crusading women’s rights advocate, found refuge in No. 29, while Paul Rudolph, the cerebral modernist and dean of the Yale School of Architecture, turned No. 23 into his personal laboratory.

headline.print_headline: In Era of Iconoclasts, Imagination Took Wing on Beekman Place
headline.main: In Era of Iconoclasts, Imagination Took Wing on Beekman Place
